title: Authors and Citation
text: Jiří C. Moravec. Author, maintainer. Lena Collienne. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Moravec JC, Collienne L (2023). rrnni: Manipulate RNNI Tree Space. https://biods.github.io/rrnni/, https://github.com/biods/rrnni.
code: @Manual{,   title = {rrnni: Manipulate with RNNI Tree Space},   author = {Jiří C. Moravec and Lena Collienne},   year = {2023},   note = {https://biods.github.io/rrnni/, https://github.com/biods/rrnni}, }

title: Manipulate with RNNI Tree Space
text: rrnni package contains collection functions create, convert manipulate ranked trees. rrnni::rnni function calculates RNNI distance two trees RNNI space.

title: Manipulate with RNNI Tree Space
text: get rrnni CRAN, type: can install latest version rrnni github:
code: install.packages("rrnni") devtools::install_github("biods/rrnni")

title: Manipulate with RNNI Tree Space
text: Create new random ranked tree 5 tips: Convert ultrametric tree, ape::rcoal, ranked tree: Calculate RNNI distance two ranked trees:
code: library("rrnni") tree = rankedPhylo(5) tree = ape::rcoal(5) tree = rankedPhylo(tree) x = rankedPhylo(5) y = rankedPhylo(5) rnni(x, y)

title: Manipulate with RNNI Tree Space
text: RNNI stands Ranked Nearest Neighbour Interchange extension classical NNI space (space trees created NNI moves) ranked trees, internal nodes ordered according heights (usually assumed times). Since ranked trees variants time trees, keep biologically relevant information timing events, splits. Note assume ultrametric trees, .e. leaves time, unique order internal nodes, means two non-leaf nodes time. RNNI distance takes tree topology account, standard NNI , also penalizes changes order internal nodes, .e. changes order times evolutionary events.

what: Useful properties of the RNNI space
title: Manipulate with RNNI Tree Space
text: RNNI space many useful biologically relevant properties. immediate interest maximum random distances. maximum distance, radius, two trees (n-1)*(n-2)/2. example, tree 5 tips, maximum distance 6. maximum distance used obtain normalized RNNI distance trees x y: rnni(x,y, normalize=TRUE). expected random distance two trees converges 5/6 diameter, .e., large enough trees, expected random normalized distance 5/6 0.8333. smaller trees (n<50), can simulate expected random normalized RNNI distance :  RNNI space multiple advantages NNI space. One advantage ranked moves make space “reticulated” inter-connected. changes geometric properties space makes possible calculate shortest path (.e., distance) two trees polynomial time, calculating distance NNI space known difficult (non-polynomial, dreadful “NP-hard”) Gavryushkin et al. (2018). theoretical, yet still biologically relevant, property RNNI space -called cluster property, cluster group related taxa. RNNI space, shortest path two trees preserves clusters. means RNNI space, small local changes tree topology big impact distance. Collienne et al. (2021)
code: library("rrnni") # define random normalized RNNI distance rnRNNI = function(n){rnni(rankedPhylo(n), rankedPhylo(n), normalize=TRUE)}  # calculate the expected rnRNNI replicate(1000, rnRNNI) |> mean()

what: More details on the RNNI space
title: Manipulate with RNNI Tree Space
text: RNNI space, allow two tree rearrangement moves (RNNI moves): NNI move can performed edge connecting nodes consecutive rank swaps neighbouring subtrees (just like standard NNI); rank move swaps order two internal nodes consecutive ranks. distance two ranked trees RNNI defined minimum number RNNI moves needed convert one tree . distance can computed polynomial time, using FindPath algorithm described Collienne Gavryushkin (2021). properties RNNI space can found Collienne et al. (2021).

what: Convert a tree to ranked tree — as_ranked
title: Convert a tree to ranked tree — as_ranked
text: Convert tree class "phylo" ranked tree class "rankedPhylo".

title: Convert a tree to ranked tree — as_ranked
code: as_ranked(x)

title: Convert a tree to ranked tree — as_ranked
text: x tree class "phylo"

title: Convert a tree to ranked tree — as_ranked
text: ranked tree class "rankedPhylo"

title: Convert a tree to ranked tree — as_ranked
text: convert tree ranked tree, tree needs binary (.e., fully resolved), rooted, ultrametric. Typically, tree produced coalescent process. Ranked trees similar time-trees, instead time, care order splits.

title: Convert a tree to ranked tree — as_ranked
code: # this will throw an error, the tree is not ultrametric x = ape::rtree(5) try(as_ranked(x)) #> Error in as_ranked(x) : Input tree must be ultrametric.  # coalescent trees can be converted without problem y = ape::rcoal(5) as_ranked(y) #>  #> Phylogenetic tree with 5 tips and 4 internal nodes. #>  #> Tip labels: #>   t5, t2, t1, t3, t4 #>  #> Rooted; includes branch lengths.

title: Find shared tip labels — common_tips
text: Find shared tip labels collection trees. function useful pruning collection related trees trees size taxa.

title: Find shared tip labels — common_tips
code: common_tips(x)

title: Find shared tip labels — common_tips
text: x collection trees class "multiPhylo"

title: Find shared tip labels — common_tips
text: intersection tip labels across trees

title: Find shared tip labels — common_tips
code: trees = rankedPhylo(3:7) common_tips(trees) #> [1] "t1" "t2" "t3"

title: Prune a tree — keep_tips
text: Prune tree collection trees keep requested tips.

title: Prune a tree — keep_tips
code: keep_tips(x, tips)  # S3 method for phylo keep_tips(x, tips)  # S3 method for multiPhylo keep_tips(x, tips)  # S3 method for rankedPhylo keep_tips(x, tips)

title: Prune a tree — keep_tips
text: x tree class "phylo" "multiPhylo" tips tip labels keep

title: Prune a tree — keep_tips
text: pruned tree collection

title: Prune a tree — keep_tips
code: tree = rankedPhylo(5) # select randomly 3 tips to keep tips = sample(tips(tree), 3) keep_tips(tree, tips) #>  #> Phylogenetic tree with 3 tips and 2 internal nodes. #>  #> Tip labels: #>   t1, t2, t5 #>  #> Rooted; includes branch lengths.  trees = rankedPhylo(3:7) # get tips from the first tree tips = tips(trees[[1]]) # prune all trees, all of them will have 3 tips keep_tips(trees, tips) #> 5 phylogenetic trees

what: Create a random ranked phylogeny — random_tree
title: Create a random ranked phylogeny — random_tree
text: Create random ranked phylogeny using coalescent method.

title: Create a random ranked phylogeny — random_tree
code: random_tree(n)

title: Create a random ranked phylogeny — random_tree
text: n number tips

title: Create a random ranked phylogeny — random_tree
text: random ranked tree class "rankedPhylo"

title: Create a random ranked phylogeny — random_tree
text: implementation ranked coalescent algorithm described Collienne (2021). Starting n tips tree, rank 0, randomly select two tips merge new node rank 1, add new node remaining tips. next iteration, assign rank 2 , single node, root, remains.

title: Create a random ranked phylogeny — random_tree
text: Collienne, L. (2021). Spaces Phylogenetic Time Trees (p. 158). University Otago.

title: Create a random ranked phylogeny — random_tree
code: random_tree(5) #>  #> Phylogenetic tree with 5 tips and 4 internal nodes. #>  #> Tip labels: #>   t1, t2, t3, t4, t5 #>  #> Rooted; includes branch lengths.

title: Create a ranked tree — rankedPhylo
text: Create new, coerce character vector existing tree ranked tree.

title: Create a ranked tree — rankedPhylo
code: rankedPhylo(x)  # S3 method for default rankedPhylo(x)  # S3 method for numeric rankedPhylo(x)  # S3 method for character rankedPhylo(x)  # S3 method for phylo rankedPhylo(x)  # S3 method for multiPhylo rankedPhylo(x)

title: Create a ranked tree — rankedPhylo
text: x numeric vector, character vector object class phylo multiPhylo, see details.

title: Create a ranked tree — rankedPhylo
text: ranked tree trees class rankedPhylo multiRankedPhylo

title: Create a ranked tree — rankedPhylo
text: wrapper multiple functions create ranked tree. , accepts multiple types inputs produce either rankedPhylo collated list ranked trees multiRankedPhylo. x numeric vector, create n = length(x) random ranked tree using random_tree function. x character vector, try read character newick-formatted tree. x object class phylo multiPhylo, coerce objects rankedPhylo multiRankedPhylo using as_ranked function.

title: Create a ranked tree — rankedPhylo
code: # Create a single random ranked tree with 5 tips rankedPhylo(5) #>  #> Phylogenetic tree with 5 tips and 4 internal nodes. #>  #> Tip labels: #>   t1, t2, t3, t4, t5 #>  #> Rooted; includes branch lengths.  # Create multiple random ranked trees with 5 tips rankedPhylo(c(5,5,5)) #> 3 phylogenetic trees  # Convert a coalescent tree into a ranked tree x = ape::rcoal(5) # random coalescent tree rankedPhylo(x) #>  #> Phylogenetic tree with 5 tips and 4 internal nodes. #>  #> Tip labels: #>   t2, t3, t1, t4, t5 #>  #> Rooted; includes branch lengths.

title: Read a newick tree — read_newick
text: Read tree newick format convert rankedPhylo

title: Read a newick tree — read_newick
code: read_newick(x)

title: Read a newick tree — read_newick
text: x single character string containing tree newick format

title: Read a newick tree — read_newick
text: object class "rankedPhylo"

title: Read a newick tree — read_newick
code: read_newick("((A:1,B:1):1,C:2);") #>  #> Phylogenetic tree with 3 tips and 2 internal nodes. #>  #> Tip labels: #>   A, B, C #>  #> Rooted; includes branch lengths.  # Note, not all valid newick trees are valid ranked trees try( read_newick("((A,B),C);") )  #> Error in .is.ultrametric_ape(phy, tol, option, length(phy$tip.label)) :  #>   the tree has no branch lengths

what: Remove values from a vector — rmv
title: Remove values from a vector — rmv
text: Remove one values vector. shorthand x[!x %% values]

title: Remove values from a vector — rmv
code: rmv(x, values)

title: Remove values from a vector — rmv
text: x vector values vector values

title: Remove values from a vector — rmv
text: x without values

title: Calculate RNNI distance — rnni
text: Calculate Ranked Nearest Neighbour Interchange (RNNI) distance.

title: Calculate RNNI distance — rnni
code: rnni(x, y, normalize = FALSE)

title: Calculate RNNI distance — rnni
text: x tree class "rankedPhylo" y tree class "rankedPhylo" normalize normalize distance maximum distance diameter (n-1)(n-2)/2 n number tips/leaves.

title: Calculate RNNI distance — rnni
text: integer RNNI distance x y

title: Calculate RNNI distance — rnni
text: RNNI distance shortest distance two trees RNNI space, defined rank NNI moves. space defined ranked trees. Non-ranked ultrametric trees can coerced ranked trees as_ranked rankedPhylo functions. distance can normalized maximum possible distance, diameter tree-space. diameter defined (n-1)(n-2)/2, n number tips/leaves. used algorithm implements TREEPATH algorithm described Collienne (2021).

title: Calculate RNNI distance — rnni
text: Collienne, L. (2021). Spaces Phylogenetic Time Trees. University Otago.

what: rrnni: Calculate a distance and a path in RNNI space — rrnni
title: rrnni: Calculate a distance and a path in RNNI space — rrnni
text: RNNI stands Ranked Nearest Neighbour Interchange extension classical NNI space (space trees created NNI moves) ranked trees, internal nodes ordered according heights (usually assumed times). Since ranked trees variants time trees, keep biologically relevant information timing events, splits. Note assume ultrametric trees, .e. leaves time, unique order internal nodes, means two non-leaf nodes time.

title: rrnni: Calculate a distance and a path in RNNI space — rrnni
text: RNNI distance takes tree topology account, standard NNI , also penalizes changes order internal nodes, .e. changes order times evolutionary events.

title: rrnni: Calculate a distance and a path in RNNI space — rrnni
text: Gavryushkin, ., Whidden, C., Matsen, IV. F. . (2018). combinatorics discrete time-trees: theory open problems. Journal Mathematical Biology, 76(5):1101-1121. doi:10.1007/s00285-017-1167-9 Collienne, L. Gavryushkin . (2021). Computing Nearest Neighbour Interchange Distances Ranked Phylogenetic Trees. Journal Mathematical Biology, 82(1-2):8. doi:10.1007/s00285-021-01567-5 Collienne, L. (2021). Spaces Phylogenetic Time Trees. University Otago.

title: Sort tip labels — sort_tips
text: Sort tip labels tree collection trees.

title: Sort tip labels — sort_tips
code: sort_tips(x)  # S3 method for phylo sort_tips(x)  # S3 method for multiPhylo sort_tips(x)

title: Sort tip labels — sort_tips
text: x tree class "phylo" collection trees class "multiPhylo"

title: Sort tip labels — sort_tips
text: input tree sorted tips

title: Sort tip labels — sort_tips
text: rnni function assumes tip labels unambiguous order. due internal implementation tip labels, tip/leave instead identified index node matrix. sort_tips orders tip labels change node indices node matrix tips two different trees taxa node id.

title: Sort tip labels — sort_tips
code: # generate random trees # use rcoal(5) instead of rankedPhylo(5) # as ranked phylo always generate tip.labels # in the same order. t1 = ape::rcoal(5) |> rankedPhylo() t2 = ape::rcoal(5) |> rankedPhylo() t1s = sort_tips(t1) t2s = sort_tips(t2) all(tips(t1s) == tips(t2s)) #> [1] TRUE  # for collection of trees: trees = c(t1, t2) sort_tips(trees) #> 2 phylogenetic trees

title: Extract tips from tree — tips
text: Extract tip labels object class "phylo" "multiPhylo"

title: Extract tips from tree — tips
code: tips(x, ...)  # S3 method for phylo tips(x, ...)  # S3 method for multiPhylo tips(x, all = FALSE, ...)

title: Extract tips from tree — tips
text: x object class "phylo" "multiPhylo" ... arguments passed methods optional extract tips trees, x "multiPhylo"

title: Extract tips from tree — tips
text: vector tip labels, list vectors case "multiPhylo" =TRUE

title: Extract tips from tree — tips
text: convenience method, purpose easily retrieve tip labels tree collection trees tip labels. Due , called collection trees (object class "multiPhylo"), first tree collection accessed. obtain tip labels trees, specify argument =TRUE.

title: Extract tips from tree — tips
code: tree = rankedPhylo(5) tips(tree) #> [1] "t1" "t2" "t3" "t4" "t5"  trees = rankedPhylo(3:7) # only the first tree is accessed tips(trees) #> [1] "t1" "t2" "t3"  # use this to obtain all tip labels tips(trees, all=TRUE) #> [[1]] #> [1] "t1" "t2" "t3" #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] "t1" "t2" "t3" "t4" #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] "t1" "t2" "t3" "t4" "t5" #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] "t1" "t2" "t3" "t4" "t5" "t6" #>  #> [[5]] #> [1] "t1" "t2" "t3" "t4" "t5" "t6" "t7" #>

title: Validate rankedPhylo class — validate_rankedPhylo
text: internal function used testing purposes. "rankedPhylo" subclass "phylo" object several restrictions given structure represented ranked tree. validate_rankedPhylo checks restrictions throw particular error, object fails restrictions.
